item.title: [SPR-981] Cannot configure CustomizableTraceInterceptor in spring-beans file
item.description:
The definition below does not work with the PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer because the PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer attempts to resolve the placeholders itself rather than leaving them to be resolved by the interceptor.

<bean
name="loggingInterceptor"
class="org.springframework.aop.interceptor.CustomizableTraceInterceptor">
<property
name="enterMessageTemplate"
value="BEGIN $

{targetClassShortName}.${methodName}({$arguments})"/>
<property
name="exitMessageTemplate"
value="END ${targetClassShortName}

.$

{methodName}

({$arguments}). Return value was $

{returnValue}

"/>
</bean>

The exception message is:

ERROR (DispatcherServlet:initServletBean) - Context initialization failed

item.summary: Cannot configure CustomizableTraceInterceptor in spring-beans file

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
I'll fix this over the weekend. I may remove the support for $

{..}

completely and possibly move to something like $[...] instead.

Rob

Changed to Rob's original suggestion of $[...] style placeholdes. Non-backwards-compatible, but we consider that tradeoff acceptable. After all, CustomizableTraceInterceptor isn't a central class, typically not used in production applications, and has just been introduced in 1.2 final.

Juergen

What about giving a warning or throwning an exception if the user uses the old style $

{...}

placeholders?

As the old style is the most intuitive style and thus users in the future could potential use this style and not the correct one.

A scan for ${ in the strings would be easy to add and throw an exception with a proper description.
